text: it turns out that I've been passionate about building design tools since I was a graduate student in fact that was my
dissertation topic where I built interactive sketching tool that would take um what you could draw on paper and turn it into a functional prototype and
so I'm really happy to re-engage that area of work and so today I'm going to talk about some recent contributions
I've made in the area of design Thinking Tools so let me just start by giving some background and motivation for my
work so a large part of my research addresses problems and opportunities that are triggered by the adoption of
software tools for the conceptual phases of design so domains of interest for me
are in interaction design um graphic design other forms of visual communication design and more recently
been thinking about technical writing and programming more from a creative perspective when I say conceptual phase
what I mean is that anything that that precedes implementation so it could be example finding it could be idea
generation it could be selection and refinement the use of software tools for
the conceptual phases of design is problematic there's a lot of friction and the reason why is that for 4 years
we have designed tools from the perspective of productivity whereas for design which is a canonical form of a
creative task we need to think about how we design them from the perspective of creativity and that Gap between
productivity and creativity is really important to close there are many compelling reasons but let me give you
the one that I think is um convincing at least to me this comes from Richard
Florida's book that he boldly calls the rise of the creative class you may have
read this one but in that book he reports that about onethird of the national Workforce is engaged in design
and other forms of creative work and that further enabling that creative class is vital to our economic and
social Prosperity one way to do that is to extend and enhance tools that that
creative class has available to work with and so I try to do this by bridging
three themes um one is what I call making and that tries to combine um computer science with HCI and reflects
my interest in building tools from an understanding of human behavior the second is creativity and this refers
both to the theory and the practice of design and other forms of creative work and theories of reflection brainstorming
and in particular creative cognition have had a large influence on what I do and it's really interesting that the past 5 to 10 years the kai Community has
really engaged that literature and the last one is crowds and this refers to
both online communities and crowd Computing and I got interested this actually from my sabatical in 2008 when
I went to Microsoft research and I had a really amazing opportunity to study one of their Innovation communities inside
the organization and it's like wow this is really amazing I wanted to make that more of a main um part of my research
it's what sabatical sabatical are for so I mapped um around the perimeter um my
recent Publications and work that I've done and I try to push my work at the intersection of those themes because I
think that's where we can make the most interesting contributions and so today I'll talk about the four um around the
top and the one thing I want to say when I go through the talk I'm simply going to describe the people that use our tools as users and not necessarily try
to tease a part if as an expert or a novice or a non-designer doing design
work I'm just say user if it matters I'll try to make the distinction so let's get started on the
first one the first project I want to describe involves helping users work more effectively with multiple ideas
during the conceptual phases of design when you tackle almost any
creative task what is the first instruction that you get generate as many ideas as you can we've known that
for a really long time so for example here uh a designer responded with multiple sketches in response to a given
design problem and say product design the theoretical basis for that goes back really far goes back to Osborne's work
on applied imagination where he argued that the best ideas come at the tail end
of idea generation so if you want to get to the really good ideas then you have to generate many
ideas the problem is that this behavior is not well supported in existing design tools or the practice of using those
tools so for instance on the left um this is kind of the dominant model in digital drawing tools where they just
assume that you're going to work with a document model and you just map your alternatives to different file names
that are apply named you know concept one concept two concept 3 and so forth and in research the way that we think
about working with multiple ideas for example could be done through a tab interface and so this is an example from
the juo system that Bjorn Hartman and Scott clad here the problem though is that other
researchers argue is that these types of representations hinder interpretation and the projection
of meaning what the heck does that mean right let me give you an example so take either of those two representations
which is the leading alternative which one is favored which one was tried but no longer in contention and which ones
are in between we can't even see all the ideas anymore I mean it's small but it's
an important part of the creative process and so what I wanted to do is
try to bring that back as best as I could and so my Approach was to explore a new model that
called interactive spatial maps and the concept was implemented as part of a prototype sketching application and the
larger window is just a very crude approximation of what you would get in a digital drawing tool and our spatial
Maps is in the lower right and it runs as a floating window it can be on your
primary display or if you want to you can move it to a secondary display if you have one and the key idea of the
spatial Maps is that we allow you to directly manipulate the representations on a zoomable workspace and so you can
project meaning by using the dimensions of both space and scale so for example the user here has a number of
Alternatives and the one that they think is favored at the moment they can scale it make it larger and position it near
the center and the one that maybe they tried but didn't necessarily like they can scale it down and position it away
and the others are somewhat in between so when you look at the workspace relative to what I showed before you should get an immediate intuitive sense
as to how they're thinking about the design situation and you can see all the ideas at once so let me just show you um
a little video clip of this in actioner is working on a tablet PC running the
team storm client software the client interface allows the designer to freely sketch on multiple canvas empis for
Rapid externalization of creative ideas standard editing features such as zooming and editing control are
supported every new idea is drawn within a new canvas and we allow users to have
as many canvases as they want ideas are managed through a resizable zoomable
floating workspace window that allows for spatial Arrangement and resizing of canvases as they come in and out of
favor selecting a canvas in the workspace makes it the focus of the editing region a colored View ER appears
on the canvas in the workspace to show the scope of the user's editing this color corresponds to the color of the
border around the main sketching window okay so that give you a sense of how it
works and we did an evaluation and I wanted to compare it to how it works with uh relative to a tab interface
that's represented say in Microsoft OneNote and a layered canvas that's represented in Photoshop so just briefly
our procedure with a was a within subjects design we had 18 users all trained in some form of visual design
and uh they used all three tools so every person used one of the three tools with one task next tool different task
and so forth and we had a number of different measures we measured process outcomes so the number of ideas the number of categories ideas the switches
between the ideas we measured um strategies that they used for how they worked with the ideas during the task we
measured their preferences and we got qualitative feedback and we had a lot of interesting findings and if you're want
to read about all of them you can look at our GI 2010 paper it's one of my all-time favorite papers and let me just give you the
highlights so one of the highlights was that users actively organize and
reflect during the idea generation task it was a core part of generating ideas and so the idea sets weren't passive
they weren't an archive people actively engaged them throughout the task to help them come up with more ideas I thought
that was really interesting when they used our tool for example they had about 10 Reflections where they look at the entire idea set
at at once and 12 organizational interactions where they' map either the idea either onto space or scale and that
was more than what they would do with the other two tools and my interpretation with that is that there's a need to engage those idea sets and
when you give people the opportunity to do it they'll take advantage of it but they also wanted more and so a couple of
the ideas that we got through the qualitative feedback was that they wanted more ways to engage that idea set
and so we went back and extended the tool to offer a grid based View could look at all the ideas at the same scale
and a Time based view so you can look at the evolution of your ideas over time and you could do um colorcoded um tags
that you would attach to the idea and you could toggle their visibility okay so they wanted different ways to look at
that um set of ideas because we allowed them to directly manipulate and organize and
reflect on the ideas there's a very strong preference for spatial maps and maybe the biggest outcome of the study
was that we showed that spatial Maps is a viable approach and an effective approach for working with ideas and so I
would love to see this be extended and implemented in the growing class of digital drawing tools that are now available through app stores as well as
um just on the web but I also think there's a lot of opportunity to really dig deeper into how people do
exploratory work and say areas of technical writing and programming and I know this has been around for really
long time but there's a lot more that we can do in the space and I hope to engage some of that work um in the future but
one of the things that really piqued my interest during this project was this notion of reflection about how people
look back to engage with things that they've done and try to extract meaning from it and that led me to Don shon's
work he has um a number of theories of reflection and reflection is a theory of
practice and he developed that theory of practice through observations of how architectural designers work in practice
he talks about many many different granularities of reflection but the one that I like the most was reflection on
action it's intentional critical thinking about prior work to learn from your experience and to project that into
the future so if you've ever looked back at say a talk or a Kai paper to think about what you might do next you've
engaged in reflection on action okay and I'm just going to call that reflection for this talk and I do it all the time I
actually did it for this talk I did it for the last paper and so forth flection typically benefits from
having a representation of design process and designers often construct
their own representations through different organizational and naming strategies so this is just an example of one that we uncovered from a study that
we did so in this case they use numbers to indicate project priority they use um letters to indicate status they have
highlights to indicate unmet dependencies and they organize iterations using folder structures it's
not that the naming schemes are bad it's just that the hierarchical representation doesn't reveal the relationships in a way that's meaningful
to the user so what did they learn from that
project what was a proud moment what was a critical incident and what I'm arguing is that you can't really know because it
doesn't come out of the visualization or the representation is short so with other
representations do you see that this these things become explicit or is this just passive knowledge that's where I'm going to go we're going to try to make
it explicit because what really kind of I love shon's Theory but what sort of kind of bothered me about it is it seemed very tacit and very implicit and
I wanted to think about what if we could actually make that explicit in a visualization so people can engage this
in a more kind of direct way so ask a slightly different question which is have you seen in other domains before
you before you left in that people do have a regular practice of this kind of yes we actually we actually predicated
what I'm about to show you on a number of interviews and studies that we did and found that people actually do engage
in fact his whole book is dedicated to to trying to communicate that people do this and it's a very important part of
of how people work in the design profession
yeah okay and I would argue that representation design process that have built in research also don't necessarily
answer those questions and so one very nice tool was done by um mles and others in Kai 2011 called freed it was a a very
nice visualization that you can construct by hand and once you had the visualization you can engage in reflection the problem is the cost of
construction works against the utility of the visualization and um others
visualizations for state-based design histories and exploratory Behavior very nice contributions but they didn't
really Target reflective behavior and that's what I wanted to do and so we created a tool called reflection space
and the key inovation of reflection space is that provides a condensed visualization of design process that
allows you to engage with the process directly it was was uh predicated on
results from interviews that we had with graphic product and Architectural designers so let me just take you
through what you see on the y- axis we have a number of channels it's called research inspiration Concepts prototype
and communication as an attempt to capture a generalized design process if you don't like that that's fine um you
can change it and configure it in the tool every filled circle is a representation of an artifact it could
be a concept sketch it could be an AutoCAD prototype it could be example that you found on the web and you can
select them and look at the thumbnails and open them up for editing on the
x-axis that is time and we cluster the artifacts based upon creation time we
use creation time because it gives us a stable representation once I place it it stays there as across implications of
the tool so just to put this in context um what you're looking at is a
visualization of process of an architectural designer who is who was think working to remodel the Dome of the
observatory at our institution and what you notice is they start with some background research in this case it was
lighting conditions they moved on to have a couple of bursts of inspirational example find in this case it was domes from around the world the second burst
was coincided with some concept sketches that they drew um followed by some AutoCAD prototypes that they created and
there was continued communication with the supervisor and peers throughout and
the point that I want to make is that you can read and tell stor about process
with this type of visualization that you cannot do with a file Centric
approach one of our challenges though is we really wanted to make this as low cost as we possibly could and so the way
that we approach this problem is that we tried to map your organizational strategy to our visualization and we use
things such as your file names your file extensions your folder hierarchies um your folder names as well as the
creation times okay and the rules are a bit more complex than what we have here but the basic idea was you could say
something like well if your file is in or is a a PDF or or a document that ends
with Doc and it's in user research background or sort combination then categorize it as research in our tool
okay and so the more closely aligned the way that you organize is with what we
expect then the lower the cost of creating the visualization if you have no
organizational strategy whatsoever then I would have to that I probably can't help you if we map it and we get it
wrong you can move it around um in the tool and that would that would actually stay um
persistent okay so one of the things that you can do with the tool is you can capture stories and the way that you
capture stories is you select the icon in the upper right and you can put it into the into what we call the reflection ction Channel Once you do
that the system prompts you to associate a number of artifacts with that story okay and a story can be anything that is
memorable to you as a designer it can be a proud moment it can be a lesson
learned it could be a critical incident but what we're trying to do is make it explicit in the visualization so you can
revisit it later on so you get prompted you can you can add and Associate um the
artifacts and you can put as many in there as you want and actually one of my favorite features of the tool is you can
come back later on and Export that into a PowerPoint presentation to share some of those Lessons Learned with
colleagues you can also Mark your favorite materials and so if you have an artifact that you're particularly proud
of you think it's inspirational you want to revisit for any reason you can mark it and we do it with a star so you can
pick as many as you want and it makes it pop out of the visualization so you can revisit it very quickly later on
on and the final thing that I'll share with you the tool actually does much more than this but I'll sh share one
other um goal that we had based upon the results of interviews that we did is that they wanted to look at the
distribution of effort and this was a very challenging problem because we didn't want to have to instrument every
application that one uses to record say editing time and so the way that we approach the problem is that we looked
at the changes to the modification date at the level of the file system and so our assumption was that every time you a
save it changes the modification date and you're not going to do a save unless you made a meaningful change and so
basically what we're do is we're counting the number of times that you essentially save that artifact we collect that data for everything that's
in the system we store it and then we rank it per Channel and we display the ones that are at the top 10% chosen
arbitrarily you can change it if you want as an unfilled Circle so that you can U make it easily identifiable
individualization so just to illustrate why that might be interesting is here's one that was there was a lot of effort
made to that particular concept and it was very early in the process so that could indicate pre premature commitment
to a concept and that might warrant a change in process or at least a discussion as to why that was the
case so we did an evaluation of this and we had seven users all trained in either
graphic or architectural design and the way that worked is that they gave us two
projects that they felt were similar in size and scope we built our representation in our system for them
because we wanted to test the utility of the visualization first not get too caught up in whether or not the mapping was perfect and then we just recreated
their own representation in the lab uh they would come in and we would engage them in a bit of Storytelling and so
they would just talk about the project by itself no representation and then with one of the two representations
other project other representation and we compared the differences in terms of the measured
outcomes they would tell more and longer stories when they used our tool in terms of word count than with other
representation and they rated it better for telling stories noticing patterns um estimating effort and just overall
preference so it's not definitive because the you know the sample size was small it was a single study but it is at least promising other interesting things
that we found is that they wanted to Mark iterations uh decisions and key milestones in that reflection channel so
you can imagine having a more kind of elaborate visual vocabulary of things that you could store there and another
thing that we found is that they would be more careful with the naming if they knew that the visualization was based upon their strategy for how they
organize things then they might change that because they knew that that would be um impacting that visualization that
would be created and the other thing is there was a lot of enthusiasm they were really interested in having a
visualization that allowed them to engage in explicit acts of reflection and that made me really excited and so
that got me to think a lot about you know how you might use this in the future and so one of the things is
everybody asked me to put my data in the cloud so what if I did that what if I put all design artifacts in the cloud
and what I'm going to argue is that that could make actually building that type of visualization really easy and you
could share it which would be really interesting to me to make it more social and the reason I think it might make it
interesting that suddenly you have access to a very large Corpus of organizational strategy that you didn't have before and so you could Analyze
That Corpus of data and you could try to build very robust mappings and then construct that type of visualization as
a value add and not just use it as a passive storage archive so I think that could be really interesting uh moving
forward so reflection space was built for an individual user but we know that
design is as much of a social process at is as it is an individual effort one of
the things that makes design a social process is that you often have to get feedback on your
ideas and so let me just illustrate with an example why this is such an important
component of
design I can summarize this as JC Penney had a really great idea for a tea cutle
unfortunately it didn't work out so well for them and it's somewhat of an amusing example but the reality was this was a
national embarrassment for JC Penney they had to take this tea kettle off all the shelves they had to issue a public
apology um they got a lot of negative press and they wound up in my
talk and so I think this is a really interesting example because it highlights one of the key reasons why
you need feedback in design and that's to compare intention to perception and
so you as a designer often always have an intent what is it you're trying to communicate and other people may or may
not get that perception it's not like when you write a paper and you're trying to say something and you think it's un
salable you give it to your adviser and it comes back with all red ink and you're like how could you not possibly get what I was trying to say and so it's
that difference between intent and perception and I would argue that good
feedback is necessary but not always easy and so there are a number of known strategies for getting feedback I mean
you can organize a critique you can ask peers you can submit to an online community but they have both benefits
and limitations and so when you organize a critique it's very heavyweight it's unlikely you're going to do that for
day-to-day decision Mak and if you're not familiar with the
with the kind of design domain you have a training in design is probably unlikely that you're even familiar with that technique at all you can informally
ask peers but we know through research that the feedback that come backs is often
overly positive um you might be reluctant to share in the first place due to the fear of criticism and my own
um work has shown that you might have a fear of interrupting other people's work you could subit it to an online
community but the research results on this um don't really paint a very Rosy picture and so the feedback that you get
often is very limited in terms of the quantity and it's relatively shallow so
you get things like wow nice job way to go versus oh wow that's really not very
good and that's really not what people want to engage with and try to get the
insights into um improving their design so I wanted to think more about
how crowds might be engaged to offer deeper more meaningful feedback and I drew a lot of inspiration from work that
Steven da and Liz Gerber did and what they had done is they used crowds to do
ab testing to collect preferences for which one you like a versus B and then as a designer you can get that signal
and try to figure out what decision that you want to make and so I love this idea but I wanted to try to push it a bit
further and think about how we could get crowds to provide more deeper more meaningful feedback the challenge is is
that crowds don't really have any expertise in design so if I show you an idea and I say what do you think of it
what do I expect somebody to say who doesn't have training in that discipline okay so that was a challenge but if I
asked the question in a different way and I said what's you know the first thing that comes to mind when you see that design what's the first thing that
you notice how is my communication goal coming through to you then you can tell me your reaction and that's something
that you can control and that Insight led to a system that we called uh voyant which is a play on the word Clairvoyant
helping you to see um and this is a system that leverages uh crowd workers a
non-expert crowd to provide feedback on uh a visual design and that feedback is
primarily perception oriented feedback and the design of the system was predicated on the results of interviews
that we did with people who had a wide spectrum of design experience from
non-designers just doing design work all the way to um expert and we asked them if you had a large audience of
non-experts what would you want to ask them and from their responses we're able to extract uh five themes and we
implemented those into the tool and so you can get elements this is literally what people can see um in the design
what first notice so what people actually see first and so establishing part of the visual hierarchy Impressions
so what's the first word or phrase that comes to mind when you look at the design guidelines um so we started with
what's known as the crap humorously principles but contrast repetition alignment and proximity and what you
would get with that is just a rating of 1 to seven about how how well people felt like your design was adhering to
each of those principles and very similar with the goals so goals are about your communication goals again you
get a rating from one to seven so the way that it works is that you go to a publicly accessible website it's called
crowd feedback. me if you have your we uh computer open you can go there now
you upload your design image and here what you have is a poster design that was done as a student design project and
the idea here was to try to engage uh customers in a restaurant to try a new smoothie station so that would be put
over the top and try to help them engage with that okay so you going try to new drink grab attention you can configure
your audience so you can configure it based upon age location gender and try to match that audience to the intended
audience that you have for the design you can configure which of the types of feedback that you want and for some of
them you can add additional parameters so if you configure the goals for instance the system would prompt you to
enter in you know with as few words as possible make it accessible to a lay person what is your communication goal
for this design you can enter as many as you want once you click submit it will
decompose that task into a series of microtasks and put it onto Mechanical Turk and the the workers are asked to do
three things very simple first give us your reaction and so if it's the task
about impression is tell us the first word or the phrase that comes to mind when you look at that
design if it's a goal or a guideline it's give us a rating on a scale of 1 to seven of how will you think that design
meets that rating or meets that guideline or goal and the second thing is do an annotation so point out the
elements in the visual design that relate to your reaction that you had and the third thing which is optional is you
can offer an explanation of why you gave the reaction and The annotation that you did and so we do this for a large number
of people and then we Aggregate and present the results back to the user and you get a visualization that looks
something like this this is the one for Impressions and if you're the the user this is what you see okay and so in this
case for Impressions we do the representation as a word cloud and so all five types of feedback back followed
the same pattern we give you an overview representation we give you um the
markers on the design that associate with each of the pieces of feedback and then the explanations so here for
example you can select the different words in the wordcloud and see which elements of have your design went with
that alternatively you can come over to the design and look at the markers and select a subset and see which words were
associated with those markers so this is all about intention
versus perception and so the person who created this design found a number of
interesting things from this so first of all you know is color colorful retro
fresh is that really what you're trying to communicate uh one of the interesting things that came out of the word cloud
was the word sunny and it turns out this was because of this element here she had
no idea that people were going to associate that with the sun it looks like the sun to me but it wasn't intentional on her another thing that
was really interesting that she learned from the feedback was people were associating the word strawberry apple
and juice with the colors in the poster and she didn't really make that intentional and what she discovered was
that she could literally make people taste her design by choosing the appropriate colors and so with a very
simple set of feedback she was learning really interesting things about what she was communicating what she was not
communicating and how she might improve
that the other set another set of feedback that you get is the ratings of communication goals and here the goals
that were entered were trying a new drink and grabbing attention Okay so
again this is supposed to be above like a smoothie station in a restaurant and try to get people to come over and try
it with this part you get a data visualization that is an interactive bar chart okay and it assesses how well
you're meeting your goals goals so in this case they did relatively well and both but trying a new drink didn't rate
as high as grabbing attention and so you could maybe sharpen that particular goal on the next
iteration the other thing the bar chart is interactive and so you can select um different bars or subsets and you can do
this um to look at some interesting patterns that we've noticed and so for example if you had a bodal distribution where certain people really like
something and others don't you can compare and contrast that feedback now there are additional types of feedback
back you get elements and first notice and guidelines and it's very similar in terms of the data representation and the
interactions that you have and I would just refer you to the the paper we have forthcoming on this and let me just talk
a bit about the evaluation what I was really interested in the evaluation is
can you actually learn anything about this feedback about your design okay so we collected eight in
progress designs and it ran kind of the gamut we had magazine covers we had 3D
renderings we had graph logos we have webpage designs and we worked with each of those um people who created the
designs to understand their goals we took uh their goals we took their designs we uploaded into our system and
once we had the feedback we asked them to come back and we talked about what they could learn as they walk through
that feedback on their own idea so I just want to share with you one anecdote that kind of exemplifies what we found
and so in this case this was a 3D rendering that the person who created it wanted to communicate two things they to
communicate Chinese style and they wanted to communicate that was a teapot okay and what they found from the
feedback both from The Impressions which are not shown and from the the goals which are shown is that it didn't really
communicate Chinese style very well and it didn't really communicate a teapot people actually perceived it as a coffee
pot and So based upon uh digging into the uh the data and digging into the
explanations they decided they would make two changes one is they would add teacups to try to convey better that it's a a tea kettle and not a coffee pot
and the second was to put maybe like a dragon pattern to better communicate Chinese style okay so the point is that
everybody learn something about their design and in many cases it wasn't just
one set of feedback it was the collection of things where they could synthesize you know interesting
ideas okay well we also tracked how much it cost and how long it took in terms of cost it was about $10 and that was
perceived as a fair trade-off because they didn't have to organize a critique or um repeatedly interrupt peers we did
absolutely no optimization and so it's really interesting to think about that as as an upper bound you know how good
could we do if we started to optimize cost to optimize quality and to optimize time the second thing is we really
emphasize finding problems and I'm okay with that because finding problems is a
significant outcome with the work how do you iterate if you don't know what you're trying to address if very hard to

decisions on a design but you know decisions are often made in a group
setting not necessarily by the individual in online communities for example um the
design discussions or this the community that often engages in design thinking in in the
discussions and um I was really interested in how that transpires you have people who have
never met and probably never will they're using a fairly impoverished interface which is the web Forum to
engage in ideation about interesting design problems so how does that work
how does it unfold and I really wanted to probe uh deeper about that one of the things that we had to do was was pick a
community that we wanted to study and we selected druple it's a very well-known
very successful open source content management system it has about 500,000 websites that have been created with
Drupal it has roughly an equal number of people that have registered to contribute to that
project the design discussions that relate to the user interface happen in
this issue queue so if you have have a feature request or a usability problem that you want to report you put it into
the issue queue and other community members can come and join and and talk about the issue offer up concrete
proposals for how to solve it engage in deliberation and then eventually if things go well you can pick one and push
it into uh the product and so we also needed to think about how we wanted to
study those particular discussions and we chose the lens of what's called consensus building consensus building
is a distinct form of decision-making where you value the social process of
the discussion as much as the final outcome and a consensus is often determined to be reached when you have a
decision and everybody can live with it we thought that was an interesting lens
to look at because the design discussions often exhibit conflict due to people advocating strongly for their
ideas and it's therefore really important for those discussions to unfold in a way that is
respectful um and well respectful and courteous
because the community depends upon people coming back and continuing to um communicate and contribute to that um
community and so we first just wanted to quantify how many of those discussions
actually reach consensus okay so we analyzed a fairly
large Corpus of the data a number of design discussions uh messages patches
and uh contributors we had a very surprising finding about 42% of the UI design
discussions do not reach consensus it's a very significant finding because of
the all the potential consequences so all the missed opportunities to improve the product um
all the effort that gets wasted into building the ideas the deliberation and it doesn't go anywhere and one of the
problems is that that could cause people to leave the community and not come back and it's actually not just drew Paul
Wikipedia has the same problem so this is an article from a recent Wall Street Journal um um article where they argue
that there's a mass Exodus of people from Wikipedia and one of the problems is that people get very frustrated with
the uh decision-making that happens so they might make a change and it gets reverted they don't understand why so if
you're frustrated with it you can just leave and not come back and it's very easy to leave and that's happening and
so um one of the really interesting things about this though when I looked at that graph is that maybe the right metric for
consensus building is not whether or not you reach an agreeable solution it's
whether you reduce the outflow of people from the community that's a very different way of thinking about
consensus building in communities than we have
today now there are many reasons why one uh why the discussions may not reach
consensus but we think part of the reason is that the web forms that people
use have no mechanism for consensus building at all so we wanted to explore you know what would it mean from a
technical side in terms of the interface to actually build in features that support consensus this is a really
challenging problem and so we we're Guided by two high level principles one is that we wanted to embed feasible and
sound strategies into the interface and our approach was to First enumerate many
different strategies that we could locate in the literature both from the theory and the practice of consensus and
then we wanted to select a subset of those that we felt were feasible and that would have utility for our
tool yet you have to be realistic I mean we're creating a tool we're not creating
a human moderator and so maybe as the first step what we thought is let's try to give people a better discussion
experience and maybe you know in the future we can try to lead and convert those discussions to a consensus but
maybe that wouldn't be a goal we could reach in the near near term and we wanted to integrate into the
existing community and this also is a really difficult challenge but all the work in uh Drupal it happens in that isq
it's where the designers are it's where the developers are it's where all the work gets done and so we wanted to have
an impact on the community and learn and discover principles of consensus through
authentic use as opposed to just creating a one-off interface that people would you say in the
lab okay so based on those goals we developed a system called proceed it's a script it runs inside the
client browser and what it does it basically rewrites the HTML um with the Drew Paul server but we also use our own

and the first thing I want to point out is on kind of the right side this is the actual discussion in the Drew Paul

discussion in that community that you want to go look at and participate in what we do is we basically wrap around
the top and along the left and so we have three different pages that we offer the homepage is what you see here what
we call an idea page with L show and an invitation page with L show one of the basic elements of consensus is you have
to know what's going on in the discussion so on the left panel we give you a number of lenses to help you do
that we help you filter comments based upon the experience of the person who submitted the comment Community
endorsement so what other people say is an interesting discussion Point um conversational Behavior so kind of a
rapid back and forth between two people and the content in terms of which messages have ideas and which have
patches and so the benefit is that you can use those lenses to help track and revisit key points of the
discussion a second strategy is including users who can help contribute to moving that discussion forward and
the way that we do this is through the invite page and we generate a list of all the community members and we show
how they score on different criteria that we know to be important for consensus in the domain so we talk about
how much experience they've had in the community the number of patches that they contributed how many threads that they've participated in that have been
closed or as a proxy for consensus and um the number interactions they've had
with people in the current ongoing discussion and so you can use this to
help fill perceived gaps and so if you're in a discussion and you're like and you wish that you had more experienced participants you can come to
this page and look at those who have more experience than what you guys have currently and you can find those who
have Bridges to people who are already engaged in the discussion because one is that will create an opportunity maybe to

rewrite the HTML on the page for authoring a comment and we inject a very
small amount of input that we request when you're authoring that comment we simply ask does this comment propose a

and so we think this is interesting because the community puts a constraint on us to think very carefully about how

y so assuming that the users will give us that small amount of input then we can render what we call an idea Centric
page and this is trying to organize the ideas or organize the discussion around
the ideas and again that's one of the kind of one of the tenants of doing consensus building it's really to focus on the idea proposals so on the left is
you get the concrete proposals that were attached to what people said were an idea you get the status you get a set of
userdefined criteria which I'll come back to and you get a set of comments that are organized in different channels
and so the top one is supportive comments the middle one is neutral
comments and the bottom one are um what we call constructive comment which is a
poite way of saying it's a critical comment and so what you can see is that you can look for ideas that need further
attention you can look for conflict you can look for things that already have good support and things that have the
lack of support and we do one other thing if you give me an extreme position either I really don't like this or I
object to it strongly or I strongly support it we render it as a slightly larger Circle to call attention to it by
the other community members and give you a sense that you have a stronger voice in the
discussion okay you can establish criteria and the
way you do the criteria is you select the icon here next to the criteria um uh
column and then it prompts you with the dialogue and you can either modify what's there or you can add an
additional set so if you add another piece of criteria it gets replicated for every idea in that same
column and what you end up with is criteria that's user defined it's visually persistent and it's interactive
and so if you want to rate how an idea um aderes to one of the criteria you can
do that with a slider and anybody in the community can do this the system prompts you to enter a comment with it to create

change should happen the last one that I'm going to
talk about that we actually do more than this is promoting a constructive tone
and so our tool realizes that this strategy in two ways first when a comment is authored the system
highlights all of the negative words okay we don't make any we don't any interpretation we're not trying to

remind you why it's a good thing to have a constructive tone and you could just choose to go forward and post it as is
or you might go back and revise it okay it's up to you and the second way is to
promote a constructive tone is that we have a constraint in the system so that when you have a new idea
the first comment has to be supportive and so we try to extract the good of an idea before people start making critical
